author: Angela Lavoipierre
title: RSL NSW council approves $99,000 spend on legal fees
text:
Map: NSW 
RSL NSW state councillors have decided the league should spend $99,000 defending them against possible expulsion. 
For months, the league's NSW branch has been embroiled in multiple financial investigations, including revelations that the former president Don Rowe withdrew $213,000 cash on a corporate credit card over a six-year period. 
His overall credit card bill between 2009 and 2014 was $475,000 — expenditure he claims was legitimate. 
The RSL national board has charged the branch with working against the league and bringing it into disrepute, by covering up Mr Rowe's conduct. 
The group faced a hearing on Friday, represented by a QC, with the help of two solicitors. 
If the charges are found to be proven, the councillors could be expelled from the league altogether . 
The ABC understands it is unusual for participants in internal disciplinary hearings to retain any counsel at all. 
However at a meeting last month, RSL NSW state councillors resolved to bill the league at least $99,000 for their legal expenses. 
A number of RSL sub-branches have criticised the council for their handling of various financial scandals. 
Both Mascot and Rooty Hill sub-branches have recently passed motions that the councillors stand down. 
A meeting of Rooty Hill members also resolved that "no RSL monies are allocated for the legal defence of named individuals". RSL sub-branches angry 
In a letter seen by the ABC, Rooty Hill sub-branch president Sean Plunkett stated membership applications have been declining in recent months, and that people at the top of the league have lost sight of its "ideals and aims". 
Mascot RSL sub-branch president Paul Graham told the ABC he is appalled. 
"The league's money is for the men lying on the bloody streets — that's how angry I am at this," he said. 
"I raise money every year from selling poppies to raising BBQs, and I look at these guys and it disgusts me". 
It is not the first time the league has been criticised for its legal bills. 
Mr Harrigan was the subject of a discrimination complaint in 2010, although he later apologised and the matter was settled in conciliation. 
It has also been revealed that a sixth state councillor, Bill Humphrey, has now stood down. 
State council asked Mr Humphrey to stand down last year, pending the outcome of an investigation into his receipt of consultancy fees from another arm of the RSL. 
All the men being investigated deny any wrongdoing.
